Award.AwardTitle: Equity in Engineering: Understanding and Promoting All Elementary School Children's Knowledge of and Motivation to Engage in Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Increasing concern in recent years has highlighted the low percentage of adults who are earning degrees and pursuing careers in engineering, and this is especially true for female and ethnic minority individuals. Given that early experiences have a profound effect on later skill development and one's motivation to learn, it is essential to target children's early beliefs and experiences to better understand and change occupational disparities later in life. Very few studies have been conducted looking systematically at young children's beliefs about engineering in majority or underrepresented populations.

This project, guided by expectancy-value theory and ability mindset beliefs, makes three critical intellectual merit contributions. First, this project is developing and validating age-appropriate measures to assess elementary school children's occupational knowledge, stereotypes, and achievement-related beliefs within engineering. Second, this project is filling a gap in the literature by examining gender and ethnic differences in children's developing occupational and stereotype knowledge and achievement-related beliefs associated with engineering. Third, this project is assessing the promise of a time-efficient and cost-effective growth mindset intervention to promote positive beliefs and performance in engineering. The project involves cross-sectional survey research methods and a randomized experiment with approximately 3,600 elementary school students and their teachers. At least half of the students who participate will be from underrepresented backgrounds. Teachers will participate in training on integrating engineering concepts into their curricula and maximizing students' motivation and engagement in engineering.

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There has been increasing concern in recent years regarding the gender and ethnic disparities within the engineering field. Given that early experiences have a profound effect on later skill development and one’s motivation to learn, we must understand children’s early beliefs and experiences if we want to change occupational disparities in engineering in the long-term. The goal of this funded project was to understand and promote engineering engagement in underrepresented elementary school students. This research has been guided by two well-established frameworks that focus on the influential role of children’s beliefs: situated expectancy-value theory (SEVT) and implicit theories of intelligence (e.g., growth mindset beliefs). The SEVT model asserts that individuals’ achievement-related outcomes are, in part, shaped by their competency, interest, and importance beliefs. Similarly, the growth mindset model focuses on beliefs about the nature of intelligence. In this view, people tend to have a fixed mindset (i.e., believe their abilities are fixed, uncontrollable traits) or a growth mindset (i.e., believe they can develop their abilities through hard work and trying new strategies). A wide body of literature has demonstrated the powerful role that achievement-related beliefs and mindsets have on children’s academic motivation and success.

Our first goal of the project was to develop and validate a suite of measures to assess children’s achievement beliefs within the engineering domain. Given that children are not familiar with the term “engineering,” a key objective was to develop new scales to measure engineering via child-relevant engineering activities and skills. To achieve this objective, we conducted a Delphi study with a panel of experts (e.g., engineers, engineering professors, teachers, and parents). Through this process, we identified a list of age-appropriate items to include in our Engineering-Related Activities and Skills (ERAS) suite of measures. To date, findings have provided evidence of the effectiveness of the ERAS in assessing engineering-related achievement beliefs in diverse children. We also found that children’s competence, interest, and importance beliefs, as measured by the ERAS, are associated with their engineering-related career aspirations.

Our second project goal was to assess if children’s achievement and stereotype beliefs differed by age, gender, and ethnicity. To date, findings have not revealed gender and ethnic differences in children’s engineering-related achievement beliefs, which illustrates promise in utilizing methodology and practices focused on activities/skills rather than broad domains (e.g., engineering). In terms of gender stereotype beliefs, we examined age and gender differences in inclusion (Who is math for?), competence (Who is good at math?), and interest (Who likes math?). Findings revealed that, overall, boys endorsed stronger stereotypes than girls, and that all age groups exhibited stronger stereotyping when making competence versus inclusion decisions, and when making interest versus competence decisions. These findings suggest that even when girls are included in STEM activities, children might still believe that boys are better at and like these activities more than girls.

A third aim of our project was to examine social influences in children’s engineering motivation. For instance, in a sample of Latinx children, we found that mothers’ perceptions of youth competency related to higher levels of youth career aspirations. Further, preliminary analyses exploring the role of peers in growth mindset beliefs, revealed that children who endorsed high levels of growth mindset beliefs gave and received more friendship nominations than children who endorsed low levels of growth mindset beliefs. We have also conducted preliminary analyses on the role of teachers. Compared to girls, teachers rated the boys in their class as having higher STEM competency and a higher likelihood to pursue a STEM career than the girls in their class. Taken together, these findings are filling critical gaps in the literature on the role of parents, teachers, and peers in children’s STEM engagement.

Our final goal in the project was to evaluate the impact of growth mindset messages. To address this aim, we implemented engineering workshops with elementary school students in 67 classrooms, with approximately half of the classrooms receiving a workshop embedded with growth mindset messages and practices. Preliminary analyses have suggested that, following the workshop, students in the growth mindset classrooms were more motivated to seek challenges and learn from their mistakes than students in the control classrooms. These findings show promise in the role that growth mindset interventions can play in promoting growth mindset beliefs associated with engineering.

The work funded on this project produced strong empirical findings to inform practices needed to broaden participation within STEM fields. At the same time, it provided educational opportunities to teachers, elementary school students, and an interdisciplinary group of undergraduate and graduate students. During this project, we have exposed 2,676 elementary school students to engineering workshops, trained 54 educators on implementing growth mindset practices, and have provided research training and practice opportunities to over 55 university students.
